tn.ref: the land where his father was staying, in the land of Canaan
tn.text: "in the land of Canaan where his father had lived"

tn.ref: These were the events concerning Jacob
tn.text: This sentence introduces the account of Jacob's children in Genesis 37:1-50:26. Here "Jacob" refers to his whole family. AT: "This is the account of Jacob's family" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"17 years old" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
This is the name of Rachel's female servant. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:28|29:29]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
This is the name of Leah's female servant. See how you translated this name in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:29:23|29:24]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"concubines" (UDB). These women were servants of Leah and Rachel given to Jacob to produce children.
"a bad report about his brothers"
This word is used here to mark a change from the story to background information about Israel and Joseph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
This refers to brotherly love or love for a friend or family member. This is natural human love between friends or relatives.
This means that Joseph was born when Israel was an old man. AT: "who was born when Israel was an old man" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"Israel made Joseph"
"a beautiful robe"

tn.ref: would not speak cordially to him
tn.text: "could not speak in a kind manner to him"

tn.ref: Joseph dreamed a dream, and he told his brothers about it. They hated him even more
tn.text: This is a summary of the events that will happen in 37:6-11.
"And Joseph's brothers hated him even more than they hated him before"

tn.ref: Please listen to this dream which I dreamed
tn.text: "Please listen to this dream that I had" (UDB)
Joseph tells his brothers about his dream.
The word "behold" here alerts us to pay attention to the surprising information that follows.
The word "we" refers to Joseph and includes all of his brothers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive]])
When grain is reaped it is tied into bundles and stacked until it is time to separate the grain from the straw.
Here the word "behold" here shows that Joseph was surprised by what he saw.

tn.ref: my bundle rose and stood upright ... your bundles came around and bowed down
tn.text: Here the bundles of grain are standing and kneeling as if they were people. These bundle represent Joseph and his brothers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_personification]])

tn.ref: Will you really reign over us? Will you actually rule over us?
tn.text: Both of these phrases mean basically the same thing. Joseph's brothers are using questions to mock Joseph. They can be written as statements. AT: "You will never be our king, and we will never bow down to you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
The word "us" refers to Joseph's brothers but not Joseph. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])

tn.ref: for his dreams and for his words
tn.text: "because of his dreams and what he said"
"Joseph had another dream"
"11 stars" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])

tn.ref: his father rebuked him. He said to him
tn.text: "Israel scolded him, saying"

tn.ref: What is this dream that you have dreamed? Will your mother ... to the ground to you?
tn.text: Israel uses questions to correct Joseph. This can be written as statements. AT: "This dream you had is not real. Your mother, brothers, and I will not bow down before you!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This means being angry because someone else is successful or more popular.
The means that he kept thinking about the meaning of Joseph's dream. AT: "kept thinking about what the dream might mean" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: Are not your brothers tending the flock in Shechem?
tn.text: Israel uses a question to begin a conversation. This can be written as a statement. AT: "You brothers are tending the flock in Shechem." (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Here it is implied that Israel is asking Joseph to prepare himself to leave and go see his brothers. AT: "Get ready" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
He is ready to leave. "I am ready to go" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"Israel said to Joseph"
Israel wants Joseph to come back and tell him about how his brother and flocks are doing. AT: "come tell me what you find out" or "give me a report" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"from the Valley"

tn.ref: A certain man found Joseph. Behold, Joseph was wandering in a field
tn.text: "A certain man found Joseph wandering in a field"
This marks the beginning of another event in the larger story. It may involve different people than the previous events. Your language may have a way of doing this.
"What are you looking for?"
"Please tell me where"
"shepherding their flock"
This is the name of a place that is about 22 kilometers from Shechem. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])

tn.ref: They saw him from a distance
tn.text: "Joseph's brothers saw him while he was far away"

tn.ref: they plotted against him to kill him
tn.text: "they made plans to kill him"
"here comes the one who has the dreams"
This wording shows that the brothers acted upon their plans. AT: "So now" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
"dangerous animal" or "ferocious animal"
to eagerly have eaten

tn.ref: We will see what will become of his dreams
tn.text: His brothers planned to kill him, therefore it is ironic that they would speak of his dream coming true, since he would be dead. AT: "That way we will make sure his dreams do not come true" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_irony]])
"heard what they were saying"
The phrase "their hand" refers to the brothers' plan to kill him. AT: "from them" or "from their plans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Let us not take his life
tn.text: The phrase "take his life" is a euphemism for killing someone. AT: "Let us not kill Joseph" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])

The negation can be placed on the verb. Also, "shedding blood" is a euphemism for killing someone. AT: "Do not spill any blood" or "Do not kill him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
This means not to harm or injure him. AT: "do not harm him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This can be translated as a new sentence: "Rueben said this so that he might rescue Joseph"
The phrase "their hand" refers to the brothers' plan to kill him. AT: "from them" or "from their plans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"and return him"
This phrase is used here to mark an important event in the story. If your language has a way for doing this, you could consider using it here.

tn.ref: they stripped him of his beautiful garment
tn.text: "they tore his beautiful garment off of him"
"beautiful robe." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:gen:37:03|37:3]].

tn.ref: They sat down to eat bread
tn.text: "Bread" is a metonym for "food." AT: "They sat down to eat food" or "Joseph's brothers sat down to eat" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: They lifted up their eyes and looked, and, behold, a caravan
tn.text: Here looking up is spoken of as if a person literally lifted up his eyes. Also, the word "behold" is used here to draw the reader's attention to what the men saw.  AT: "They looked up and they suddenly saw a caravan" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"carrying"
"seasonings"
an oily substance with a sweet smell used for healing and protecting skin. "medicine"

tn.ref: traveling to carry them down to Egypt
tn.text: "bringing them down to Egypt." This can be made more explicit. AT: "bringing them down to Egypt to sell them" ([[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: What profit is it if we kill our brother and cover up his blood?
tn.text: This can be written as a statement. AT: "We do not gain a profit by killing our brother and covering up his blood" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This is a figure of speech referring to hiding Joseph's death. AT: "hide his murder" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"to these men who are descendants of Ishmael" (UDB)

tn.ref: not lay our hands upon him
tn.text: This means not to harm or injure him. AT: "not hurt him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: he is our brother, our flesh
tn.text: The word "flesh" is a metonym that stands for a relative. AT: "he is our blood relative" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] ).
"Judah's brothers listened to him" or "Judah's brothers agreed with him"
Both names refer to the same group of traders that Joseph's brothers meet.
"for the price of 20 pieces of silver" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:translate_numbers]])
"took Joseph to Egypt" (UDB)

tn.ref: Reuben returned to the pit, and, behold, Joseph was not in the pit
tn.text: "Reuben returned to the pit, and was surprised to see that Joseph was not there." The word "behold" here shows that Reuben was surprised to find out Joseph was gone.
This is an act of deep distress and grief. This can be written more clearly. AT: "He was so grieved that he tore his clothes" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: The boy is not there! And I, where can I go?
tn.text: Reuben uses questions for emphasis the problem that Joseph was missing. These can be written as statements. AT: "The boy is gone! I cannot go back home now!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This refers to the beautiful garment that his father made for him.
"the goat's blood"
"they brought the garment"
"has eaten him"

tn.ref: Joseph has certainly been torn to pieces
tn.text: Jacob thinks that a wild animal has torn Joseph's body apart. AT: "It has certainly torn Joseph to pieces" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This is an act of deep distress and grief. This can be written more clearly. AT: "Jacob was so grieved that he tore his garments" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "loins" refers to the middle part of the body or the waist. AT: "put on sackcloth" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here the childrens' coming to their father is spoke of as "rising up." AT: "came to him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: but he refused to be comforted
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "but he would not let them comfort him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: Indeed I will go down to Sheol mourning
tn.text: The means that he be mourning from now until when he dies. AT: "Indeed when I die and go down to Sheol I will still be mourning" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"The Midianites sold Joseph"
"the leader of the soldiers who guarded the king"
